content: Jose Rizal was born in Calamba, Laguna
Jose Rizal was baptized by Rev. Rufino Collantes
The church of Calamba where Rizal's baptismal records were stored, were burned
Learned alphabet from his mother at three years old
His sister Conception died
His mother taught him how to read and write
He made a pilgrimage to Antipolo with his father
He wrote his first poem "Sa Aking Mga Kabata"
He began schooling under Justiniano Aquino Cruz at nine years old
He left Binan for Calamba
He attended school in Calamba under Master Lucas Padua
Dona Teodora was arrested on malicious charge that she aided her brother, Jose Alberto in poisoning his wife.
Cavite mutiny flared up
He heard the execution of GomBurZa
He took entrace exam at the College of San Juan de Letran and passed them all.
His father decided to send him to Ateneo instead of Letran
He was the first to use the surname "Rizal" to avoid association with Fr. Jose Burgos
He went to class composed of peninsular, Spaniards, insulars, mestizos, and natives
He was the source of ridicule from his classmates by having crude knowledge of Spanish
Finished the first year of Philosophy and Letters and transferred to a medical couese
He took a vocational course for Expert Surveyor at Ateneo
He wrote a poem for a competition, but lost for discrimination
He won the first prize for the allegory "El Consejo de los Dioses"
Ateneo Municipal de Manila produced Rizal's operetta "Junto al Pasig"
He wrote another poem for the Ateneo rector
He became secretary of the Academia de Ciencias Filosoficonaturales
He left for Europe with the steamship Djemnah
He joined Masonry intending to use as a shield to combat friars
He was conferred the degree of Licentiate in Medicine
He finished Philosophy and Letters with a grade of excellent.
He moved to Paris, France to specialize in Opthalmology
He had his grand tour of Europe
He arrived in Manila from Europe via Hong Kong
He formed La Liga Filipina
He was arrested for establishing La Liga Filipinas
He was exiled to Dapitan
He won the lottery of P20,000 with Francisco Equilor
He described his peaceful life in Dapitan to his friend Ferdinand Blumentritt
Dona Teodora with her eyesight was fully restored and returned to Manila
He gave a letter to his sister Trinidad praising Josephine
He wrote a poem in Dapitan entitled Mi Retiro per his mother's request
He and Josephine gave a Christmas party at their home in Talisay
He gave his writings to his sister Trinidad describing his last Christmas party
He was kept under arrest for 27 days aboard cruiser Castilla, anchored off Canacao, Cavite
He sent a letter to his sister Narcisa asking her to let Josephine Bracken send him pants, vests, collars, and cuffs
He advised his parents and sisters how they could visit him on board the Castilla
He thanked his sister Narcisa for letting Josephine stay in her house
Gov. Ramon Blanco sent Rizal a letter recommending him to the Minister of War
He was transferred to the boat Isla de Panay
He was advised by a military sergeant to pack his things
The Spanish authorities confiscated his diary, and bought back to him after a few days
He was found guilty by a Spanish court for sedition, rebellion, conspiracy, and was sentenced to death
It was decided that Rizal will be executed by musketry
He was transferred to his death cell in Fort Santiago
He walked to the place of execution
He was shot and fell down backward facing the sun.
